com.supenta.flitchio.sdk

Class FlitchioController

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.supenta.flitchio.sdk.FlitchioController

  • public class FlitchioController
extends Object
    Object providing the main communication channel to the Flitchio Manager app. This is the most important component of the Flitchio SDK, and the only object you have to manipulate in order to use Flitchio with your app.

    The controller binds to the Flitchio Manager app when you call FlitchioController.onCreate(). You need the Flitchio Manager app to be able to use Flitchio, otherwise a FlitchioManagerDependencyException will be thrown. When FlitchioController.onCreate() returns true, the binding is going to be effective soon in the future, but you can't use FlitchioController.isConnected() or FlitchioController.obtainSnapshot() yet. You can listen to the moment the binding gets effective by implementing FlitchioListener.onFlitchioStatusChanged(boolean). To free the controller properly, you must call FlitchioController.onDestroy().

    After initialisation and as soon as this controller is bound to the Flitchio Manager app, you can check if Flitchio is attached to the phone by calling FlitchioController.isConnected() and poll data from it by requesting a FlitchioSnapshot of its state with FlitchioController.obtainSnapshot(). You typically call FlitchioController.obtainSnapshot() if you want to use your controller in polling mode, i.e. if your app is designed to have a rendering loop updating the display at high frequency. That's typically the case for games that use a SurfaceView or a GLSurfaceView.

    If you don't want to actively poll data from Flitchio, but rather receive events every time something has changed on the device, you can use your controller in listening mode. To do so, simply register a FlitchioListener with FlitchioController.onResume(FlitchioListener) and unregister it with FlitchioController.onPause(). You will then receive ButtonEvents for button presses/releases and JoystickEvents for joystick position updates, as well as updates about the connection status of Flitchio.

    Since:
    Flitchio-0.5.0

    • Method Detail

      • getInstance

        public static FlitchioController getInstance(Context context)
        Get an instance of FlitchioController for this Context.
        Parameters:
        context - The context used to bind. It should be the Activity / Service, not the Application's context.
        Returns:
        An instance of FlitchioController.
        Since:
        Flitchio-0.5.0

      • getPlayStoreIntentForFlitchioManager

        public static Intent getPlayStoreIntentForFlitchioManager()
        Get an Intent to download the FlitchioManager app on the Play Store.
        Returns:
        An intent to open the PlayStore on FlitchioManager page.
        Since:
        Flitchio-0.5.0

      • getVersionCode

        public static int getVersionCode()
        Get the SDK version code used in the JAR. This returns the "android:versionCode" value defined in the Manifest.
        Returns:
        The version code of the SDK.
        Since:
        Flitchio-0.5.0

      • getFlitchioManagerVersionCode

        public static int getFlitchioManagerVersionCode(Context context)
                                         throws FlitchioManagerDependencyException
        Get the version code of FlitchioManager installed on the system. This corresponds to the "android:versionCode" attribute in the Manifest of Flitchio Manager.
        Returns:
        The version code of Flitchio Manager.
        Throws:
        FlitchioManagerDependencyException - If FlitchioManager is not installed.
        Since:
        Flitchio-0.5.0

      • onCreate

        public boolean onCreate()
                 throws FlitchioManagerDependencyException
        Initialise the FlitchioController. This method verifies the presence of the Flitchio Manager app and binds to it. It must be the first method to be called, in the onCreate() method of your Activity / Service. At the moment this method returns true, the binding is not yet effective. To be notified as soon as the binding is done, you should declare a FlitchioListener and implement FlitchioListener.onFlitchioStatusChanged(boolean).
        Returns:
        True if the FlitchioController is going to get bound.
        Throws:
        FlitchioManagerDependencyException - If Flitchio Manager was not found or is too old and needs to be upgraded.
        Since:
        Flitchio-0.5.0

      • onResume

        public void onResume(FlitchioListener listener,
                     Handler handler)
        Register a FlitchioListener to receive callbacks. If you use this FlitchioController in an Activity, this should be called in your Activity's onResume() (hence the name). If you use this FlitchioController in a Service, this can be called right after FlitchioController.onCreate(). You only need to call this if you declare a FlitchioListener.
        Parameters:
        listener - The listener.
        handler - The handler associated to the thread on which the callbacks will happen.
        Since:
        Flitchio-0.5.0

      • onResume

        public void onResume(FlitchioListener listener)
        Register a FlitchioListener to receive callbacks. If you use this FlitchioController in an Activity, this should be called in your Activity's onResume() (hence the name). If you use this FlitchioController in a Service, this can be called right after FlitchioController.onCreate(). You only need to call this if you declare a FlitchioListener.
        Parameters:
        listener - The listener.
        Since:
        Flitchio-0.5.0

      • onPause

        public void onPause()
        Unregister the FlitchioListener that has been previously declared. If you use this FlitchioController in an Activity, this should be called in your Activity's onPause() (hence the name). If you use this FlitchioController in a Service, this can be called as late as in your Service's onDestroy(). You only need to call this if you have declared Listener with FlitchioController.onResume(FlitchioListener).
        Since:
        Flitchio-0.5.0

      • onDestroy

        public void onDestroy()
        Terminate the FlitchioController. You won't be able to get data or callbacks from Flitchio after this call. This should be called in the onDestroy() method of the Activity / Service.
        Since:
        Flitchio-0.5.0

      • obtainSnapshot

        public FlitchioSnapshot obtainSnapshot()
        Retrieve the latest state of Flitchio as a FlitchioSnapshot. Attention: before the binding is effective, this will always return an empty snapshot. You can listen to the moment the binding gets effective by implementing FlitchioListener.onFlitchioStatusChanged(boolean).
        Returns:
        The snapshot representing the latest state of Flitchio. It is never null: when Flitchio is disconnected, you get an empty snapshot instead.
        Since:
        Flitchio-0.5.0

      • isConnected

        public boolean isConnected()
        Check if Flitchio is connected. Attention: before the binding is effective, this will always return false. You can listen to the moment the binding gets effective by implementing FlitchioListener.onFlitchioStatusChanged(boolean).
        Returns:
        True if Flitchio is connected and data can be read from it.
        Since:
        Flitchio-0.5.0
